location.town: Hinaplanon, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Duk

texts.en: Duk D., 37, is a district policeman who started his job more than nine years ago. He has a partner in his wife, who works sewing clothes for MV garment industry. The couple has been married many years, and they have three young school-aged children. Duk D. has a piece of land in a good location for rent, on which he hopes to build a few rental rooms, but he doesn’t have the money yet to start the construction process. Therefore, he is pursuing a loan to buy housing materials, and he then will hire a worker to build new rooms for his service.

loans.use: To build new rooms for his service

loans.name: Clarisse Nadine

texts.fr: Née en 1973 à Dassa-Zoumé, dans le département des Collines au Bénin, A. Clarisse Nadine vit depuis 6ans au quartier Hlacomey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à HOUNNOU K. Pascal avec qui elle vit, Clarisse Nadine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple se partage les charges de la famille. Pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, Clarisse Nadine vend de la farine de manioc à Tokpa kpodji, marché international du Bénin. C’est à Azovè et Ikpinle, deux marchés de vente de produits vivriers au Bénin que Clarisse Nadine se ravitaille. Clarisse Nadine a déjà quinze ans d’expérience dans l’exercice de son activité mais n’avait encore jamais obtenu de prêt à AlIDé. C’est dans le but d’accroitre son capital et d’élargir son activité que Clarisse Nadine sollicite un prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1973 in Dassa-Zoumé, in the Collines department in Bénin, A. Clarisse Nadine has been living for 6 years in the Hlacomey district in Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin. Married to and living with HOUNNOU K. Pascal, Clarisse Nadine is the mother of four children, all enrolled in school. The couple share responsibility for supporting the household.

In order to help with family expenses, Clarisse Nadine sells manioc flour at Tokpa kpodji, international market of Bénin. She buys her inventory at Azovè and Ikpinle, two marketplaces where foodstuffs are sold in Bénin. Clarisse Nadine already has 15 years' experience in her business but has not yet received a loan from ALIDé. She is requesting her first loan from ALIDé with a view to growing her working capital and expanding her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of bags of 100 kg of manioc flour

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda D. is a simple woman who has simple dreams in life. 

As a mother and a wife, she wishes to remain healthy and live longer so that she can continue to take care of her husband and children, as well as her grandchildren in the future.  She hopes to grow her tricycle (a motorcycle with a sidecar) for hire business with the loan she is requesting now from ASHI, Kiva field partner in the Philippines.  

In addition to her other sources of income, such as providing laundry services (hand washing) and selling food, Yolanda envisions that the profits from her tricycle-for-hire business will help her see her two children achieve their own dreams in life. Her elder child, a 25-year-old high school graduate, and her 51-year-old husband will manage the tricycle since now they are now unemployed.  Her younger child is accumulating large amount of expenses in school, since she is 20 years old and in her fourth year college. To be able to sustain her daughter's education until graduation, which they expect soon, and to change the kind of life they are experiencing now, Yolanda’s husband and son must help her earn an income. 

Through loans she can requests through ASHI, Yolanda is very much hopeful that someday she will make it happen.

loans.use: To purchase a tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) for a transportation-for-hire business.

loans.name: Rosalie's Group

texts.en:
Rosalie L. is from the village of Mozzozzin Norte, Sta. Maria, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Rosalie is the leader of a 15-member loan group offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Rosalie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalie owns and operates a business venture raising livestock. While this is not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and for sale. Rosalie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rosalie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock, feed, and other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rosalie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock, feed, & other supplies

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys W. M. is thirty-eight years old, married, and has two children. Her business is located at Ngong, a busy area in Nairobi, and is known by the name "Mwea General Shop." She has been serving the local people for the last two years, and her major challenge is that there are so many people engaged in the same kind of business as hers that customers are spoiled with choices. She is using her loan to buy maize and wheat flour, soft drinks, and cereals. She hopes to expand her business and become a wholesaler. She is a very hard-working business lady.

loans.use: Soft drinks, flour, and cereals

loans.name: Pon

texts.en:
Mrs. Pon M. lives in Kandal Kaoh Touch village in the Kandal province. She is 48 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are construction workers while the others are studying at local public schools.

She and her husband, Mr. Nhor Oran, are farmers who own 1.2 hectares of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. In farming, they face a problem because they do not have enough money to buy vegetable seed, fertilizers, and fuel to pump the water necessary to support the field and make their crops more productive. Therefore, Mrs. Pon M. has decided to apply for a loan for these purchases.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seed, fertilizers, and fuel for farming

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Suong

texts.en: Mrs. S. is a 35-year-old farmer with many years of farming experience. She is a married mother of three teenage children, two of whom are students and one of whom is a garment factory worker. She has a partner in her husband, which allows her to plant crops. S. is requesting a loan to buy planks in order to replace the broken wall of her old house.

loans.use: To buy planks.

loans.name: Pao

texts.en:
Mr. Pao P. is 59 years old and lives in Toul Sala village in the Kandal province. He and his wife, Mrs. Ly Min, are farmers who own a piece of land for cultivating rice to earn a living. 

On this plantation, they face a problem because their field does not have enough water to support the rice field. Thus, Mr. Pao P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a watering machine to support the field. 

Mr. Pao P. has two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other is employed in the World Vision organization.

loans.use: To buy a watering machine to support the field

loans.name: Abass

texts.en: Abass is a 28-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon. Abass has owned a barber shop for nine years already. Abass requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to change the décor of his shop and purchase beauty products and tools. This is his second cycle, and he has always paid on time. Abass is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and does good work. His clients are his friends, neighbors, and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t have enough cash to purchase all the needed tools for his shop. Abass decided on this business because he wanted to have independent work, because he learned it in an academy, and, more importantly, because he likes his job. In the future, he plans on improving his business by purchasing more sophisticated tools.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products and tools

loans.name: Ayaba Georgette

texts.fr: H. Ayaba Georgette est née le 09 Mars 1972 à Allada dans le département de l’Atlantique. Depuis près de 7 ans, Ayaba Georgette vit dans le quartier Yénawa à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à NOUGBODE DJEDJE Toussaint, Ayaba Georgette est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. C’est avec ses enfants et son mari que Ayaba Georgette vit. Le conjoint assure la plupart des charges familiales. Mais Ayaba Georgette vient en aide à son mari en ce qui concerne l’entretien et l’éducation des enfants, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Ayaba Georgette a arrêté les classes au cours secondaire, puis a appris la coiffure. Ayaba Georgette a un atelier de coiffure à son domicile et exerce cette activité depuis environs 12 ans. A côté de cela, Ayaba Georgette vend des mèches et d’autres produits de cheveux et de beauté à son atelier. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Ayaba Georgette s’approvisionne. Auparavant, Ayaba Georgette n’avait jamais obtenu de crédit à ALIDé. Ayaba Georgette sollicite ce premier crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue d’augmenter son stock de produits et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
H. Ayaba Georgette was born on March 9, 1972 in Allada in the 'Atlantique' region. For nearly 7 years, Ayaba Georgette has been living in the Yénawa district in Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin. Married to NOUGBODE DJEDJE Toussaint, she is the mother of two children, both enrolled in school. She lives with her husband and children. Her husband is the chief breadwinner for the family, but Ayaba Georgette helps him with the responsibility of taking care of and educating the children, thanks to the income from her little business.

Ayaba Georgette left off her studies in secondary school and learned to do hairdressing. She has a hairdressing salon in her home and has been in this business for about 12 years. Moreover, Ayaba Georgette sells hair extensions and other hair products and cosmetics in her salon. She gets her merchandise in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin.

Ayaba Georgette has never before received a loan from ALIDé. She is requesting this first loan from ALIDé, in order to add to her stock of products and better satisfy the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of hair extensions, cosmetics, and hair care products

loans.name: Gallido

texts.en:
Gallido M. is from the village of Del Carmen, Iligan City. He is 35 years old. Gallido is single. To make a living, Gallido owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily-use products in the local community. Gallido has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gallido joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gallido is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gallido from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

location.town: Luinab, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Samer

texts.en:
Samer is a 33-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Samer has owned a shoe shop since 2004. Samer requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase the new spring shoe collection. This is his second cycle, and he has always paid on time.
Samer is special in his work because he knows how to treat his client and offers good quality shoes. His clients are people from his region, but mainly his neighbors and friends. When he first started his business, he didn’t have enough cash to expand his stock; therefore, thanks to his previous loans, he was able to expand and diversify his merchandise. Samer decided on this business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his business by always providing his clients with the best merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase the new spring shoe collection

loans.name: Edna

texts.en: Since the time Edna P. became a member of ASHI, a Kiva field partner in the Philippines, she has invested her loan into her rice farming business. Both she and her husband work in this business. Edna’s husband rents tricycles from other people in their village to save for his family’s daily expenses while waiting for the harvest time. Edna has a small “sari-sari” (variety) store in their village that sells the most common commodities to help her husband earn money to save for her weekly repayment to ASHI. Last year, Edna and her husband both agreed to buy a tricycle of their own so that her husband would no longer have to rent from other people. With that, income will increase, and they will have their own productive asset. Since Edna paid up her previous loan from ASHI early this year, she is requesting a much larger loan to materialize the business plan she and her husband agreed on. Through the profits they will make, Edna envisions that someday all of her five children, whose ages range from 11 to 23, including her month-old grandchild will graduate from college and have a better career. For herself, she wishes that she will be able to have money through her profits to spend on her dream of having false teeth.

loans.use: Will be used to purchase a tricycle (motocycle with sidecar) for a transportation-for-hire business

loans.name: Sary

texts.en: Mrs. Sary M. is 54 years old and she lives in Kbal Kaoh village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Ros Sim, are farmers who own a 2-hectare field to cultivate both rice and vegetables. For rice farming, they own a water machine to support their crop field. They face some problems because their field contains infertile soil and has a lot of insects. Thus, Mrs. Sary M. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides, and she would use the rest of the loan to buy gasoline to pump water to support the field. Mrs. Sary M. is a mother of two children, one of whom is employed in the garment factory, and the other is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mazen

texts.en: Mazen is a 31-year-old man who lives in Saida in southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Mazen owns a small bakery where he makes mankoucheh. Mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza. The most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Mazen is an active man who is doing his best to improve his family’s income. He requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase a new oven and raw materials for his bakery. This is his second loan and he has always paid on time. Mazen is speciA. in his work because he is known for his good mankoucheh. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Mazen decided on this business because he wanted to have independent work.

loans.use: To purchase a new oven and raw materials for his bakery

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: B. Jeanne est née en 1963 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Jeanne s’est installée à Yénawa, un quartier de Cotonou, depuis 15 ans environs. Jeanne est mariée à HOUNSOU Nicolas et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Yénawa. Jeanne vient en aide à son mari, en ce qui concerne l’entretien et l’éducation des enfants, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. En effet, Jeanne n’a pas fréquenté l’école, mais vend depuis une dizaine d’année, des boissons en cannettes dans sa boutique. Jeanne s’approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois crédits auprès de l’institution. Jeanne a bien remboursé  ces trois crédits. Jeanne envisage augmenter le stock de ses produits et diversifier son activité par la vente de divers autres produits ; ce qui lui permettra de mieux satisfaire les demandes de ses clients. Mais compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose, Jeanne sollicite un quatrième crédit pour agrandir son activité.
texts.en:
B. Jeanne was born in 1963 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She became situated in Yénawa, a district of Cotonou, about fifteen years ago. She is married to HOUNSOU Nicolas and is the mother of two children, who are both in school. The family lives together in Yénawa. Thanks to the revenues she earns from her business, Jeanne works in aid of her husband where it concerns maintaining the children's education. Basically, Jeanne did not attend school, but she has been selling canned drinks in her store for ten years. She stocks up in Lomé, Togo, a country neighboring Benin. She is a previous client of ALIDé having already obtained three loans from it. She has repaid these three loans. Jeanne envisions increasing her inventory of goods and diversifying her business by selling a variety of other products. This will enable her to do better in satisfying the demands of her customers. But due to few financial means available to her, she is requesting a fourth loan to expand her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying canned drinks

loans.name: Mam

texts.en: Almost all of the people who live in Kampong Chhnang province earn a living as a basket weaver. One of these people, Mrs. Mam S., operates her own small handicraft business, mainly weaving bamboo baskets. She has a partner in her husband, who assists her with weaving and selling items. The couple is blessed with five children; one is married and the others are single and working. Mam S. owns a small house that is overcrowded for her family. So, she has requested a loan to add to her personal savings in order to build a new house.

loans.use: To build a new house.

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
BilA. is a 36-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. BilA. has owned a barber shop for over 15 years. BilA. requested a loan from A. Majmoua, a Kiva partner, in order to change the décor of his shop. This is his third loan and he has always paid on time.

BilA. is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and he does a good job. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t have enough cash to purchase all the tools he needed for his shop. BilA. decided on doing this business because he wanted to have independent work and because he leaned it in an academy. In the future, he plans on improving his business by purchasing more sophisticated tools.

loans.use: To change the décor of his shop

loans.name: Siem

texts.en:
Mrs. Siem K. is 36 years old and lives in Popeal Khae village in the Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Tim Mao, are farmers who own a plot of land for cultivating rice. Aside from having this plantation, they are vegetable sellers in the local market. 

Since their business is doing well, they want to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Siem K. decided to request a loan to buy more vegetables to resell. She hopes this loan will increase their income and improve the family's living conditions. She has five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while three are attending the local school and one is too young to work or study. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to resell

loans.name: O. Rosine

texts.fr: F. O. Rosine est née en 1979 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a six ans que Rosine vit à Hlacomey à Cotonou. Mariée à KINMAGBAHO Kevin, Rosine est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Rosine vit ensemble  avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Rosine n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Pour venir en aide à son mari, Rosine vend du maïs à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est à Nikki et à Kandi, dans le Nord du Bénin, que Rosine achète ses produits.  Rosine n’a jamais obtenu de crédit à ALIDé. C’est dans l’optique d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux satisfaire la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de ses clients, que Rosine sollicite un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
O. Rosine F. was born in 1979 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has lived for the past six years in the Hlacomey district of Cotonou. Married to Kevin KINMAGBAHO, Rosine is mother of three children, all in school. Rosine lives together with her husband and children. The couple share the household expenses. Rosine has never attended school. To assist her husband, Rosine sells corn in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. She buys her suppies in Nikki and Kandi, in the Northern part of Benin. Rosine has never before been granted a loan from ALIDé. She is now requesting a first loan from ALIDé with the intent of increasing her stock of supplies and satisfying the growing demands of her customers.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 100-kilo bags of corn

loans.name: Eng

texts.en: Mrs. Eng T., 40 years old, owns a small wooden house and a grocery shop, where she sells many items, including cooking ingredients, sweets, and soft drinks. Eng T. sells her inventory to passers-by and also neighbors living near her house. She has been running her grocery shop for a long time and earns an average of $5 a day. To ensure financial stability for the entire family, her husband works farming rice. The couple now lives with three children who are going to school. Eng T. is taking out her loan to increase her inventory for her grocery store. (Mrs. Eng T. was busy at her business, so her husband is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To increase her inventory for her grocery store.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 33 years old and has a farm in the Bureti district of the South Rift Valley in Kenya. Happily married, he has four children, aged four through ten. But he says that life has not been an easy ride with three of his children attending school. He opted to take out a loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 45,000 to add an extra dairy cow. This will improve his milk production and enable him to pay school fees and repay the loan.

David also grows tea in addition to the milk that he produces and sells to Kenya Cooperative Creameries. He's been farming for three years and, in the future, he'd like to build dairy units for four cows that can produce up to 60 litres a day. He says that the main challenges to his business are lack of capital and of knowledge of high-yield dairy farming, both of which he is now acquiring through Juhudi.

About Juhudi Kilimo

Juhudi Kilimo is a for-profit social enterprise focused on the economic development of Kenya, where agriculture and related activities employ about 75% of the workforce, often in smallholder farms. Through micro-leasing, Juhudi helps these smallholder farmers acquire productive, income-generating assets like dairy cows, chickens, and agricultural equipment. Farmers also receive agricultural training and business insurance as part of Juhudi’s innovative approach to creating sustainable growth and employment in these rural communities. Juhudi is changing the way farmers do business.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Kov

texts.en: Mrs. Kov M. is a widow and she lives in Popeal Khae village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns one-hectare field to cultivate rice. She faces an obstacle because her field is not very fertile and she can't grow much, so she does not enough money to support herself or her family well.  Thus, Mrs. Kov M. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, and would use the rest of the loan to buy pesticide to use on her rice field. Mrs. Kov M. is a mother of two children, one of whom is employed in the public sector and the other is employed in an organization.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides for a small rice farm.

loans.name: Filomina

texts.en:
Filomina M. is 38 years old, single and was ill for 24 years of her life. Just recently, she had the courage to undergo an operation to remove a cyst from her ovary. One of the reasons why she had to endure the ailment she had for so long was because she lacked the money to pay for the operation.  Moreover, she felt she had no one encouraging or supporting her morally.

Filomina lives with her 69-year-old mother and she acts as a provider for herself, mother, and other close family relatives. It was through ASHI, one of Kiva's field partners in the Philippines, that she had savings which she used to spend for her operation. Loans from ASHI have also enabled her to start up and maintain a small “sari-sari” (variety) store business. Little by little, Filomina’s business is growing, but it's not growing as fast as she'd hoped because  the living expenses incurred by her family and the cost of her medicine is almost equal to her income.

Filomina’s health is now in better condition after her operation, and she's gotten good post-operative results from her doctor regarding her condition. She is excited to grow her “sari-sari” store. She wishes to increase the inventory of goods in her store for the convenience of people in their village, which is far from the main market.  Moreover, Filomina wishes for a better kind of life for both her mother and herself. Therefore, for her dreams to come true, she is  requesting to borrow a much larger amount from ASHI this time.

loans.use: To purchase inventory of goods/foods for a "sari-sari" (variety) store.

loans.name: Anita

texts.fr: Née en 1983 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, C. Anita vit depuis 7 ans environs au quartier Dédokpo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à GOVOU Arnaud, Anita est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Cependant, Anita ne vit pas avec son mari. Anita  supporte donc seule, les charges de son enfant. Anita a fréquenté jusqu’au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de son enfant, Anita mène comme activité la vente de tissus, par le système de distribution. Anita a déjà sept ans d’expérience dans ce domaine. C’est à Lomé au Togo, pays voisin du Bénin, que Anita achète ses produits. Anita a bien remboursé le premier crédit qu’elle a obtenu de ALIDé. Anita sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé, dans le but d’augmenter le stock de ses produits, en vue de mieux satisfaire la forte demande de ses clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1983 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, C. Anita has been living for about seven years in the Dédokpo district in Cotonou.  Married to GOVOU Arnaud, she is the mother of one child who is in school  However, she doesn't live with her husband.  She is therefore alone in supporting her child.  Anita attended secondary school only.  To provide for herself and her child, she has a business selling cloth through the distribution system.  She already has seven years of experience in this domain.  Lomé, in Togo, a country neighboring Benin, is where she purchases her goods.  Anita has repaid the first loan she obtained from ALIDé.  She is requesting a second one from ALIDé with the goal of increasing her stock of goods, so as to satisfy further the strong demand from her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying bolts of fabrics

loans.name: Mi

texts.en: Mrs. Mi C. is 49 years old and she lives in the village of Kandal Koh Touch in Kandal Province. She and her husband, Mr. Sython Chheng, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice and vegetables.  They now face a problem because they do not have enough money to support their farm adequately. So, Mrs. Mi C. is applying for a loan to buy garlic seed, onion seed and fertilizer. Mrs. Mi C. is a mother of six children, three of whom are employed at a garment factory, and three of whom are students at a local school.

loans.use: To buy seed and fertilizer.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Alberto

texts.en:
Alberto T., 53, is making sure that his family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Melba T., he is blessed with three children. He is making sure that his family will have a better future. He has been selling fruits and vegetables for more than a year.

Alberto has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. He regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays his weekly dues consistently. Because of his good repayment performance with his previous loans, he was able to borrow  a few times in CCT’s Cooperative, a Kiva partner. He is consistent in paying his dues because he used the money he borrowed to buy assorted fruits and vegetables from wholesalers. His business lets him earn a profit of 15,000 Philippine pesos per month.  

Now with your help, he would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to his expanding business by allowing him to buy more stock of assorted fruits and vegetables.

He dreams that his earnings from his business will continue to grow so that he can continue to finance his children's education until they finish college. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying more stock of assorted fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion S., 52, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Armando S., a retired businessman, she makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that they can have a better life. Both of them have been managing their own variety store for a year.

Salvacion S. has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT), a Kiva partner, for more than four years. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow several times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy added stock for her store. Her business lets her earn a profit of 6,250 Philippine pesos per month.  

Now, with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to buy assorted canned goods, snacks, beverages and toiletries for her store.

She dreams that her store will continue to grow and become a mini grocery someday so that she can help with the schooling of her grandchildren. 


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying assorted canned goods, snacks, beverages and toiletries for her store

loans.name: Albert

texts.en:
Albert M. is 61 years old. He lives with his wife and son in their own house in Tsakhkunk village, Sevan area. Albert has been a driver for about 20 years and also, together with his family he is engaged in stock-breeding. They have 3 cows, 30 sheep and 4 calves in their farm.

Albert uses the profit from stock-breeding activities for his family's needs. His business is located on his private land. Now Albert M. needs 1,100,000 AMD as a loan to buy some more cows.

loans.use: To buy some cows

loans.name: Noélie

texts.fr: Née le 25 décembre 1961 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, F. Noélie est mariée à SAMARI Taïrou avec qui elle vit. En effet, il y a environs 24 ans que Noélie vit à Sègbèya-nord, un quartier de Cotonou. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par Noélie et son mari. Pour aider son mari à subvenir aux besoins de la famille, Noélie exerce comme activité la vente de maïs, de soja et de mil, par le système de distribution. Noélie s’approvisionne à Tchaorou, une ville du nord du Bénin. Noélie exerce son activité depuis environ dix huit ans mais n’a encore jamais bénéficié d’un concours auprès de ALIDé. C’est dans le souci d’augmenter son stock de produit et d’étendre ses activités que Noélie sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born on December 25, 1961 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. F. Noélie is married to Mr. SAMARI Taïrou, with whom she lives.  She has in fact lived in Sègbèya-Nord, a district of Cotonou, for about 24 years.  The couple has two children who are both in school.  Family expenses are covered by her and her husband.  To help her husband provide for the family, Noélie operates a business selling corn, soybeans, and millet through the distribution system.  She stocks up in Tchaorou, a city in northern Benin.  For about eighteen years, she has been in this business but still has never benefited from assistance from ALIDé.  Concerned about increasing her stock of goods and expanding her business, Noélie is requesting a loan from ALIDé. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of corn, soybeans, and millet

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda A. is undeniably a happy woman. Being a mother and a wife, she maintains her family’s harmonious relationship. Her husband and her four children are loving and supportive to one another. No matter how busy Merlinda is with her business, she makes sure that she has time to attend to her family's needs, be it at home or in the schools of her children.

Aside from her family, Merlinda’s other inspiration is the opportunity of having been trusted with a loan through ASHI, KIva field partner in the Philippines. Through credit she has accessed since the time she became a member, her dream of having a fishing and fish-selling business has eventually came true. It started off very small and little by little, after each loan, it has grown and has been helping many fishermen in their village.

Through Merlinda’s loan she can buy a large volume of fish caught by other fishermen in their village. Using a motorcycle driven by her husband, she sells the fish in other villages of their remote municipality in the province of Antique. Her customers from the two neighboring municipalities come to their house to buy tons of fish to sell once Merlinda calls them and informs them that she has plenty of fish. This happens about four times a week.

Merlinda’s motorcycle is being paid for in installments every month. However, Merlinda would like to fully pay her remaining balance to maximize her profit in growing her business. Therefore, she is requesting a larger loan for that purpose; some of it will be used for additional capital since growing a business needs bigger capital.

Despite being a woman, Merlinda also goes fishing in the sea together with her husband, wanting to achieve her dreams of giving her children and grand-children a better life. She hopes that through her business proceeds she will be able to complete the house she and her husband are building for themselves, and that someday all of their kids will graduate from college and have their own careers and not the hard life she and her husband have had since birth.

loans.use: to fully pay for the motorcycle they bought on installments

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca B., 52, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Carlos B., a machine operator, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for more than a year. She also sells prepaid mobile phone credits.

Rebecca has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for eight months now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow few times from CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy added stock for her store. Her two businesses let her earn an extra profit of 18,000 per month.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as added capital for her expanding business, buying assorted beverages, snacks, and toiletries.

She dreams that her business will grow and that their standard of living will improve as well.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying assorted beverages, snacks and toiletries for her inventory

loans.name: Mrs. Na Yours Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Na Y. is the village bank president chosen by the members of this twelve-person group. In this group, loans will be used for different purposes; these people are located in Kaoh Reah Kraom village, Kandal province.

Mrs. Na Y. is a cake seller to earn her family's living. Since her business earns only meager income, she wants to expand it. So, Mrs. Na Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ingredients to make cakes. Her husband, Mr. Chhin Chav, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to grow crops on. Mrs. Na Y. is 54 years old and the mother of two children who both are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to make cakes

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
A young dairy farmer from Chebwagan in the South Rift Valley of Kenya, Anthony is aged 28. He is married and blessed with two young children. He previously took a loan for Kes. 45,000 from 'Juhudi Kilimo' and repaid it on time. He now wants to improve his milk production by acquiring an extra quality cow with this new loan for Kes. 70,000.

Anthony has been farming for three years and sells his milk to Kenya Cooperative Creameries. He also earns income from a small retail shop and a motorbike taxi business. He says that the main challenges to his business are a lack of capital and of knowledge of high-yield dairy farming, both of which he is now receiving from Juhudi. In the future, he hopes to improve his farm by building a modern dairy unit to accommodate five cows, producing up to 70 litres of milk every day.

About Juhudi Kilimo

Juhudi Kilimo is a for-profit social enterprise focused on the economic development of Kenya, where agriculture and related activities employ about 75% of the workforce, often in smallholder farms. Through micro-leasing, Juhudi helps these smallholder farmers acquire productive, income-generating assets, like dairy cows, chickens, and agricultural equipment. Farmers also receive agricultural training and business insurance as part of Juhudi’s innovative approach to creating sustainable growth and employment in these rural communities. Juhudi is changing the way farmers do business.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Edith

texts.fr: Née en 1971 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, A. Edith vit depuis environs 5 ans à Enafa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Edith est mariée à GOUNADIN Paulin et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Edith vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Edith vient en aide à son mari, en ce qui concerne les charges de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Edith n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Il y a près de 17 ans que Edith mène comme activité, la vente de produits vivriers (maïs, haricot, etc.) à son domicile. C’est à Bohicon, dans le département du Zou au Bénin, que Edith se ravitaille. Edith a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Edith n’arrive plus à satisfaire tous ses clients, compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose. Edith sollicite pour cela, auprès de ALIDé, un deuxième crédit, crédit qui lui permettra d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux satisfaire tous ses clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1971 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. A. Edith has been living for about five years in Enafa, in the community of Sèmè-Podji, in Benin.  She is married to Mr. GOUNADIN Paulin and is the mother of four children, who are all in school.  She lives together with her children and husband, and she helps him out where family expenses are concerned, thanks to the revenues she brings in from her business. Edith never attended school.  For nearly seventeen years, she has been operating a business selling staple foods (corn, beans, etc.) out of her home.  Bohicon, in Zou county in Benin, is where she resupplies herself.  She has already benefited from an ALIDé loan, which she has repaid.  Facing more and more numerous demands from her customers, she is no longer managing to satisfy them all, given the few financial means at her disposal.  And so, Edith is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.  This loan will enable her to increase her stock of goods and to do better in satisfying all her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying100-kg sacks of beans and corn

loans.name: Rosejean

texts.en:
Rosejean B., 33, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Zacarias B., a Jeepney driver, she is blessed with one child who is in grade school. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. Aside from managing their tricycle business, she also sells prepaid mobile phone credits.

Rosejean has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) since last April. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow four times from CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows for the maintenance and improvement of her tricycle business. Her business lets her earn a profit of 16,500 per month.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business, buying tricycle parts and for the renewal of license and permit.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can save for her child’s schooling and fix their house.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying tricycle parts and renewal of license and permit

loans.name: Delphine

texts.fr: F. Delphine est née en 1978 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à GBETCHOU Robert, Delphine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Delphine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Agbato à Cotonou, depuis environs 5 ans. Delphine vient en aide à son mari pour assurer les besoins de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Delphine  n’a pas été à l’école. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Delphine vend divers produits (couscous, lait, œufs, riz, dentifrices, comprimés, etc.) à son domicile. Delphine vend également des liqueurs à son domicile, ce qui lui permet de multiplier ses sources de revenus. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Delphine s’approvisionne. Delphine exerce son activité depuis environs sept ans, mais n’a encore jamais bénéficié de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité afin de mieux satisfaire la demande nombreuse des clients, Delphine sollicite un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Delphine F. was born in 1978 in Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. Delphine is married to Robert Gbetchou and the mother of four school-aged children. Delphine and her husband and children have been living in the Agbato quarter of Cotonou for the last five years. She helps her husband meet their family's needs with the income generated from her business. Delphine never attended school. To cover expenses, she sells various products (couscous, milk, eggs, rice, toothpaste, pills) from her home. She also sells liquor from her home, which allows her to increase her source of income. Delphine gets her provisions at Dantokpa, Benin's international market. She has had her business for roughly seven years, but has yet to benefit from an ALIDé loan. Delphine is soliciting her first loan from ALIDé with the intention of expanding her business to better suit the needs of her many clients.

Translated from French by Owen Frivold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of liquor and various products  (cans, sugar, milk).

loans.name: Loryn

texts.en:
Loryn B., 26, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Marvin B., an electronics repair man, they are blessed with one child. She makes sure to contribute to her household's earnings so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own "sari sari" (variety) store for several years.

Loryn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) since April last year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she previously borrowed to buy more stock for her business.   Her business lets her earn a profit of about 12,850 Philippine pesos per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to get a 12,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used as a source of additional capital for her expanding business, with which she plans to buy beverages, assorted snacks and canned goods.

Loryn dreams that her business will grow and be more profitable, so that one day her family can buy their own house.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy beverages, assorted snacks and canned goods for resale at a small variety store.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina R. owns a small “sari-sari” (variety) store in the far, distant village of Dumrog in Pandan, Antique. She was able to start this business when she became a member of ASHI in 2004. Cristina took the risk of taking out a loan then and started taking a step toward achieving her dream of a better life for her family. The endeavor she chose was supported by her loving husband. Despite poverty, Cristina now is happier than before because she has her own business and is playing a productive role as a wife and mother. However, growing her “sari-sari” store into a grocery store that has a complete inventory of goods which people can access without spending money for going to the market would make her complete. Her dream of a better life for her family is anchored to this goal; thus, it needs to be achieved. 

Cristina is hopeful that through ASHI, a Kiva field partner in the Philippines, she will be able to have a larger amount of capital to materialize her dream for her business and family. She wants to increase the inventory of her goods little by little as the amount of the loan she is qualified to request from ASHI also grows. With the people who work with the poor like Kiva and ASHI, Cristina is hopeful that someday she will be able to bring her family out of the shadow of poverty.

loans.use: Will be used to purchase inventory of goods/foods for her "sari-sari" (variety) store business

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: Née en 1987 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, A. Christine vit depuis cinq ans au quartier Agbodjèdo  à Cotonou. Mariée à HOTEGNI Jacob, un commerçant, Christine n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Vivant maritalement, Christine est mère de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Christine vient en aide à son mari pour assurer les besoins de la famille grâce aux revenus que lui procure son activité. Comme activité principale Christine vend des produits vivriers (lait, riz, œuf, pates alimentaires etc.) et parallèlement à cela elle commercialise les produits de la SOBEBRA (Société Béninoise de Brasserie). Christine exerce son activité depuis environs 4 ans mais n’a encore jamais bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Dans le but de renforcer son activité pour mieux faire face aux besoins de la clientèle sans cesse croissante, Christine désire obtenir un prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1987 in Cotonou, Benin's economic capital, Christine A. has been living in the Agbodjèdo quarter of Cotonou for the last five years. She is married to Jacob Hotegni, a shopkeeper, and never attended school. Christine lives with her husband and is the mother of three school-aged children. She helps her husband meet their family's needs with the income generated from her business. Her primary business is selling staple foods (milk, rice, eggs, doughs, etc...) but she also markets SOBEBRA (Benin Brasserie group) products. Christine has had her business for roughly 4 years, but has yet to benefit from an ALIDé loan. Christine is requesting a loan from ALIDé with the purpose of reinforcing her business and meeting the needs of her ever-growing number of clients.

Translated from French by Owen Frivold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of staple products (doughs, rice, canned foods, milk, sugar, eggs)

loans.name: Pajero Group

texts.en:
Jambo from Tanzania!

This is Iddy S. and the Pajero loan group from Dar es Salaam. The group named itself after the Pajero car. There are sixteen men and women in this group. In the photo Iddy is second from the left in the back row wearing a white cap. 

Iddy S. is 41 years old, married and has one son who is 11. He has been operating a "duka," or shop, since 2007 where he sells items like oil, soap, sugar, tea, matches and other household items. His duka is open from 6am until 9pm every day. Iddy's shop is named "Father D Shop" and is located in the Kunduchi area of Dar es Salaam. This is a very popular area near the beach and Iddy, therefore, often runs out of stock. He buys more stock three times a week. Iddy is able to employ his younger brother at the shop and makes a monthly profit of 300,000 Tanzanian shillings (~$225 USD). 

This will be Iddy's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, Ltd. He repaid the first one successfully. When asked about his future plans for his business Iddy says that he wants his shop to grow very big. He hopes that eventuA. he will make enough profit to buy a "pikipiki" (Swahili for "motorbike") to help him transport stock. Iddy says, "I feel very happy about getting this loan because I was down before, but now I'm going up and up a little at a time". Thank you for your support of Iddy and the Pajero loan group in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania!

loans.use: To buy sugar, oil, soap, matches and other items for store

loans.name: Soda

texts.en: Ms. Soda F., aged 41, has been a member of her local Kiva partner UIMCEC branch since 2003.  She lives and works in the Cité Lamy neighborhood of Thies, a city about 50 miles from the sprawling capital, Dakar.  Ms. F. is now on her sixth loan from UIMCEC and she will use it to finance her activity: selling perfumes and a local incense, Thiouraye.  She has been a commercante (trader) for twenty years, and she says the revenue helps make ends meet in her household where she and her husband take care of their two children and two young nephews.

loans.use: To stock incense and perfumes.

loans.name: Sayeed Khalid

texts.en: Sayeed Khalid, son of S., lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single and is an educated man. His father was a pilot in the army but, during the war in Afghanistan, he was injured. He left the army and Khalid then started a business by opening a retail shop that he is still running. Sayeed Khalid would like to expand his business so he wants an individual loan of 50000 Afghani to buy notebooks, biscuits, pens and pencils. He wants to increase his stock so that he can make a good income and help his family. He is happy that he can expand his business with this loan.

loans.use: He wants to buy more stock for his shop

loans.name: Peace Group

texts.en:
Jambo from Tanzania!

This is the Peace loan group from Dar es Salaam. Their group leader is Bilali A. (pictured in the center of the front row wearing a gray and black shirt between the woman in the blue dress and the woman in the green dress). 

Bilali is a 42-year-old father of three. He is married and his children are 13, 11, and 7 years old. Bilali runs a "genge"-which is Swahili for a table-top fruit and vegetable stand. He has been in the business for three years, operating from 7 a.m. til 6:30 p.m. every day. He manages to make about 700,000 Tanzanian shillings per month in profit (~$525 USD). This will be Bilali's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, Ltd. He repaid his previous two loans on time and is excited to have his third loan. 

Bilali will use this loan to increase the stock and range of his fruits and vegetables. He and the members of the Peace group thank you for your kind support!

loans.use: more fruits and veggies for table-top food stall

loans.name: Murodbeg

texts.en:
N. Murodbeg is 36 years-old. He buys and sells cattle from different market places and has been in the business for the last 10 years. His main customers are butchers and livestock farmers. He is requesting a second loan after successfully repaying a first one. With the previous loan, Murodbeg was able to increase the number of heads that he trades. Murodbeg is married and the father of three children. With the loan from Kiva, he plans to increase his herd of cattle for trading and, if possible, open up his own butchery. This, he says, will increase his turnover. He hopes to see his children complete higher education and to get good jobs unlike himself.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule and it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  Today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty. 

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Kodirjon

texts.en:
Kodirjon is a farmer, not only devoted to his work but also to being the father of a family. He works hard to raise cattle, which he takes out to graze in the early mornings. Without a doubt it is not an easy task, but the love for his family gives his work reason and meaning. In the photo you can see Kodirjon’s mother who also helps in this business. Currently, Kodirjon wants to improve his situation by increasing the number of his cattle which in the long run will provide better financial income. If you support him, he will be forever grateful.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule and it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Nurali

texts.en:
A. Nurali has always been a hard-working man, who has made sure, from a young age, that his family never goes without their daily bread. He is married with two children. Nurali has a grocery store where he sells different kinds of food. Thanks to his perseverance and dedication he began his business 10 years ago with a starting capital of $200 USD. Today, Nurali needs to buy additional food to increase the range of his goods for sale. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of 4,000 Somoni. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push in order to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

loans.use: To purchase food to sell.

loans.name: Djamoliddin

texts.en:
Djamoliddin is married, 26 years-old and has two children. He began his business four years ago with a small store, which adapted according to the market demand. Initially, Djamoliddin offered a small number of bricks and other construction materials to his buyers but in time it expanded due to his location and the needs of his clients. Djamoliddin is asking for a loan of 4,700 Somoni to purchase merchandise for his business in order to offer a more diverse range of products to his clients. In this type of business, novelties always appear. He wants to be able to keep an up-to-date inventory and meet the preferences of his clients. Djamoliddin thanks you for your support to allow him to continue to better both his business and the quality of life for his family.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule and it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.en:
K. Gulnora is 37 years old. She is divorced and has two children. Gulnora has been selling clothing for kids for the past five years. With her savings she started to travel to the neighboring towns to buy clothing and then sell it at the local market of Dushanbe. Little by little she increased her number of clients and expanded her business. Nevertheless, her current selection of garments is poor; therefore, she requests a loan of 5,000 MNT. With this loan Gulnora can purchase new and varied merchandise to offer her clients.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase kids' clothing to sell

loans.name: Norbibi

texts.en:
S. Norbibi is married and has seven children. She runs a small business selling rice in the local market. Her place is located on the main market aisle where there are many customers every day. Norbibi has been in this business for over eleven years. She is a high achiever and a consistent entrepreneur who is very knowledgeable about the market environment. Her professional skills and perseverance have helped to ensure the rapid growth and success of her business. 

Norbibi is requesting a loan of 5,000 TJS to increase the assortment of her selling inventory. She is hoping that this loan will help her venture grow and generate extra profits. We believe that Norbibi's ability to identify tasks critical to business success, and to set up a system for accomplishing them, will allow her to continue growing in the sphere of private entrepreneurship.

loans.use: To increase the range of her selling inventory.

loans.name: Kanyanya

texts.en:
Kanyanya Z. N. is forty-three years old, widowed and has three children aged 25, 18 and 9. Her business is located at Sabasaba in Thika, where for the last nine years she has been selling milk to the local residents, walk-in customers and to Kamahuha Secondary School on order. She also sells doughnuts and eggs. Her business is situated outside Thika and is well known by the name Super Milk Bar.

During some seasons milk production goes down, and at times the animals get sick and hence she is not able to sell milk and maximize on profits. But she is determined to grow in this kind of business, which she really loves. She is using her loan to buy more milk for sale and she sees herself buying her own cows to be able to supply in larger quantities and even buy a vehicle to facilitate transportation of milk to the consumers. She has a dream to educate her children and to ensure the best for them. She is a faithful, respectful and responsible businesswoman.

loans.use: to buy more milk for sale

loans.name: Hudson

texts.en:
Hudson A. O. is 50 years old, and married with seven children. His wife is a farmer and their children are still schooling.

His business is located at Tindiyo in Kakamega. Kakamega is a town in the western part of Kenya where sugarcane cultivation is the major farming activity. It is well known as the sugar belt region.

Hudson’s business is located along a busy highway where for the last four years he has engaged in selling meat to the local people and the local schools as well. He has managed to employ two people and he has hopes to be the best supplier of meat in Tindiyo.

Despite his financial obligations, Hudson has managed to keep his children in school. His dream is to give them quality education and also to own his own business premises.

Hudson’s major challenges are transporting the cows and some of his customers refusing to pay their debts. He will use his loan to buy more cows to supply more meat to the people of Tindiyo. Hudson is very strict and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy cows for more meat supply.

loans.name: Kaberael

texts.en:
Kaberael is a 40-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife. Kaberael has owned a butcher shop for over fifteen years. When he first started his business, he had some financial issues because the cost of his machines is high. 

He decided to operate his shop because he learned the business when he was young, and now has taken over his father's business. Kaberael is well known for his business because of the good quality of the meat he sells. His clients are his friends, neighbors and people from his region.

He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to repair one of his machines. This is the first time that Kaberael has requested a loan. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his work by always providing the best to his clients.

loans.use: To repair one of his machines.

loans.name: Mouhyee Eldi

texts.en:
Mouhyee Eldi is a 37-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Mouhyee Eldi has owned a mobile shop since 2006. He repairs and sells new and used mobile phones, as well as their accessories like covers, earphones, memory sticks and telephone recharge cards. 

When Mouhyee Eldi first started his business, he didn’t face any difficulties because he is well known in his region and does a lot of networking. He decided to start his business because he wanted to have independent work. He is exceptional in his work because he knows how to treat his customers. His clients are his friends and neighbors.

He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase more mobile phones and their accessories. This is the first time that Mouhyee Eldi has requested a loan. In the future, he plans on expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phones and their accessories.

loans.name: Afissa

texts.en:
Afissa is 38 years old, married with four children aged between 6 and 12 years old. She also takes care of one dependent from another family who is 14 years old. Afissa lives in Nyakabungo, the Western province of Rwanda. Her business is well organized and it is open from 6 AM to 9 PM every day. This is her 7th successful year in this business of selling foodstuffs.

Afissa is requesting a Kiva loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more foodstuffs including vegetables, beans, fish, etc. With these additional foodstuffs for sale, Afissa will be able to satisfy the demand of her customers as well as earning more profits in the process. This, in turn will allow her to reinvest in business so that she and her devoted husband can continue to pay school fees for their children, provide more food for them and save some for their future.

loans.use: More foodstuffs to sell like vegetables, beans, etc.

loans.name: Mirvah

texts.en:
Mirvah is a 37-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with her husband and their child. Mirvah has been selling jewelry for almost two years now. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. Mirvah decided to start her business because she wanted to supplement her family’s income. She sells necklaces, earrings and bracelets, as well as handmade jewelry. Her clients are her friends and neighbors.

She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new jewelry models. This is the first time that Mirvah has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. In the future, she plans on expanding her work.

loans.use: To purchase new jewelry models.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase more shoes for sale

loans.name: Money Tree Group

texts.en: Marie C. is a leader of a group of five borrowers called Money Tree Group. She is 36 years old and is married with two children, ages 3 and 4. Both of them are in the nursery educational level. Marie and her family live in Gbange Town, but work around the V.O.A. gas station community in Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. She was never able to go to school herself due to lack of financial support from her parents. Marie’s business is the sale of food such as cassava, fufu, coconut and plantain. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail to residents of the V.O.A. community in Monrovia. She has been running this business for five years and hopes to become both an importer and exporter of goods in the near future. Marie started selling with 500.00 Liberian Dollars in working capital, but now operates with about 8500.00 Liberian Dollars. She sells good products and also has a good working relationship with her customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Marie will use this loan as working capital to improve her business. She dreams of getting her children educated and getting a house of her own. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Marie is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy cassava, fufu, coconut and plantain for resale

loans.name: Adelfa

texts.en:
Adelfa B. is a single woman who supports her family by running a general store. She lives in Barangay Binicuil Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 45,000.

Adelfa B. is now borrowing PHP 20,500 so that she can increase inventory levels in her general store. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 22,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Adelfa B. aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: God's Gift Group

texts.en:
Sarah B. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'God’s Gift'. She is 45 years old and is married with 5 children aged 24-34 years old; none of her children had the opportunity to go to school due to poverty. Sarah and her family live around the E.L.W.A Junction but work in the E.L.W.A market about 4 miles away from downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She was never able to go to school herself due to lack of financial support from her parents.

Sarah’s business is the sale of kitchen utensils such as spoons, plates, sets of pots, etc. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail from a tabletop in the E.L.W.A market in Monrovia. She has been running this business for 20 years and hopes to improve her business to a shop in the near future.

Sarah started selling with 1000 Liberian Dollars as capital that was given to her by her husband. Sarah faces difficulty with the rainy season, because when its rains, a lot of people don’t come out to buy anything. She gives her customers big smiles whenever they come to buy from her in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. She has been saving from her business; this is why her business has grown to this level. Sarah needs this loan as working capital for her business. She plans to buy more kitchen utensils for resale. She dreams of educating her entire family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Sarah is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy kitchen utensils such as spoons, plates, and pot sets for resale

loans.name: Solange

texts.en:
Solange was born in 1984; she is married with one child who is 2 years of age. She lives with her family in the northern province of Rwanda, which is approximately two hours from the capital, Kigali. Her husband is a technician; they both work hard for their family. Solange has owned a shop selling different kinds of goods including drinks such as juice, mineral water, ripe bananas, etc. Before this business, Solange was a full-time housewife and she was not able to contribute toward the life of her family. She has been in business for one year. Her shop is open from 6 AM to 9 PM every day and she employs one person from her community as a helper so that her business runs well.

Solange is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to purchase more products which will make her more efficient, effective and more successful. She thinks with these products she will be able to attract more customers as well as earning more profit which in turn will allow her to build a secure future for her family.

loans.use: additional products including drinks like juice, mineral water, ripe bananas, etc.

loans.name: Nabil

texts.en:
Nabil is a 47-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Nabil has owned a bakery since 1994. He makes 'mankoucheh'. A 'mankoucheh' looks like a folded pizza. The most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning.

Nabil is special in his work because he is known for his good and tasty 'mankoucheh'. His customers are his friends and neighbors. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials for his bakery. This is his fourth loan and he has always repaid on time.

Nabil is well known in his neighborhood thanks to his years of service. He decided on doing his business because he had always wanted to open up a bakery. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for his bakery

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia M. is a 46-year old married woman who lives in Brgy. Maitom Siaton, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by fishing and operating a fish vending business.

Amalia’s husband, Edelberto, is 49 years old and is a fisherman. They have one adult child. The family dreams of improving their living conditions and sustaining the needs of their family.

Amalia M. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999, in the hopes that she would be able to help her husband improve their family's quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase the family's income. Now, she earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000 from her business activities.

Amalia M. is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 10,000 was used to fund operations of her food vending business, and it had a positive impact, on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 16th loan, in the amount of Php 15,000, which she intends to use on the food vending and carinderia (local eatery) business. Amalia is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for food vending and carinderia (local eatery) business

loans.name: Antoine

texts.en:
Antoine is 27 years old and single. He lives in Ruhengeli in the northern province of Rwanda, Burera district, and is still living with his parents. Antoine socializes with his parents after coming back from his daily work.
