texts.es: Rosa Cándida P. D. M. D. 40 años D. edad, resiD. en Ciudad Arce, ubicado en el departamento D. La Libertad. Vive junto a su esposo y dos hijos menores D. edad, los cuales son estudiantes D. educación básica. Rosa se dedica a venta D. ropa, la cual la comercializa D. manera ambulante por las calles D. Ciudad Arce, obteniendo ganancias diaria, Rosa sale D. su hogar cada mañana con la esperanza D. poder vender una mayor cantidad D. ropa que el día anterior, ya que a pesar que su esposo cuenta con un trabajo fijo, su salario es bastante bajo, situación la cual llevó a Rosa a desempeñar su propio negocio. Ella es una mujer muy trabajadora quien se diviD. entre los quehaceres del hogar, el cuido D. sus hijos y su negocio, todo este esfuerzo lo realiza con la esperanza D. poder tener una vida mejor. Rosa solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar diferentes tallas, estilos y colores D. ropa, tanto para mujeres como para hombre y D. esta manera incrementar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Rosa Candida P. D. M. is 40 years old and lives in Ciudad Arce, located in the Department of La Libertad. She lives with her husband, and two young children who are in elementary school. Rosa earns money by working every day as a traveling saleswomen selling clothing in the streets of Ciudad Arce. Rosa leaves her home every morning with the hope of selling more clothes than she did the day before. It is important since, although her husband works and has a regular income, it’s quite low. This is the reason that Rosa decided to have her own business. She is very hardworking and divides her time among her household chores, taking care of her children, and her business. All of this she does with the goal of a better life. Rosa requests a loan so that she can buy clothing in different sizes, styles, and colors, both for men and women, and in this way increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy different sizes and colors of clothing

location.town: Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Edelina

texts.en:
Edelina P. is from the village of Lower Mainit, Iligan City. She is thirty-six years old. Edelina is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Edelina owns and operates a specialized retail business venture in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling gold. Edelina has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Edelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edelina is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Edelina's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Lower Mainit, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Ana De La Paz

texts.es: Ana de la Paz H. M. de 45 años de edad, reside en Puerto el Triunfo, ubicado en el departamento de Usulután. Vive junto a su familia la cual está conformada por su esposo quien trabaja como vigilante, y tres hijos de los cuales el  mayor trabaja como jornalero y los dos pequeños se dedican a estudiar. Ana posee una venta de tortillas, en la cual se encarga de elaborarlas y venderlas. Su negocio está ubicado en el Mercado municipal de Puerto el Triunfo, lugar con mucha afluencia de personas, el cual tanto personas de afuera como personas que trabajan ahí, le compran tortillas a Ana. Ella solicita un préstamo por medio del cual cuente con la capacidad económica para comprar maíz al por mayor, con el fin de poder obtenerlo a menor precio. Ana espera  poder vender mayor cantidad de su productos es por ello que desea invertir en materia prima, la cual le permitirá atender más clientes y de esta manera obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Ana de la Paz H. M. is 45 years old. She lives in Puerto el Triunfo, in the Department of Usulután. She lives with her husband, who works as a security guard, and three children, the oldest of whom works as a day laborer; her younger children are both students. Ana owns a business where she makes and sells tortillas, it is located in Puerto el Triunfo’s well-attended municipal market. In addition to the customers who come to the market, other vendors and people who work at the market also buy Ana's tortillas. She has asked for a loan to buy corn on a wholesale basis, that is, at a lower price. Ana would like to make the investment in the staples in the hope that she will be able to sell more of her product, attract more customers and earn more.

Translated from Spanish by Montserrat Zuckerman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn

location.town: Puerto el Triunfo, departamento de Usulután

loans.name: Patria

texts.en:
Patria P. is from the village of Kiwalan, Iligan City. She is fifty-six years old. Patria is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Patria owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Patria has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Patria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Patria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be Patria's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Kiwalan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Chit

texts.en:
Chit C. is a low-income person who earns a living by selling fruit in Battembang Province. She is married and does not have any children. Her husband supports the family by selling fish. 

Chit C. wants to buy a piece of her neighbor’s land, which is in good location for farming. She has been trying to save money to buy the land, but her savings is not enough. Therefore, she would like a loan that will allow her to buy the land. She will earn additional income by renting her new land to crop growers.

loans.use: To buy land

loans.name: Zuleima Esmeralda

texts.es: Zuleima Esmeralda D. de 34 años de edad, reside en Cuscatancingo, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador. Vive junto a sus dos hijos de 14 y 4 años de edad. Ella posee una cafeteria, la cual está ubicada frente al Centro de Gobierno de El Salvador, lugar en el cual tiene 10 años de comercializar sus productos, razón por la cual los clientes la prefieren, sobre todo, los empleados que trabajan en el lugar. Zuleima solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda surtir su negocio comprando materia prima para la elaboración de desayunos y almuerzos, así mismo bebidas, galletas y golosinas, entre otros productos más. Zuleima es una persona muy querida en el lugar, ya que siempre la han conocido como una mujer muy trabajadora la cual se ha esforzado por brindarles todo lo mejor a sus hijos, los cuales dependen absolutamente de ella, ya que Zuleima es madre soltera y es la única que vela por el bienestar de sus hijos, es por esto que para ella es de mucha importancia mantener a flote su negocio y seguir adelante junto a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Zuleima Esmeralda D. is 34 years old. She lives in Cuscatancingo, Department of San Salvador, with her two children, ages 14 and 4. She owns a coffee shop in front of the Government Center of El Salvador. She has been selling her wares in the same place for the past 10 years. Her business is favored by her customers, and especially by people who work in the area. Zuleima has asked for a loan to buy the staples she uses to make breakfast and lunch items, as well as drinks, cookies and candy, in addition to other products. Zuleima is well liked in the area; people know her as a hard worker who has done her best to provide for her children, who are solely dependent on her. Zuleima is a single mother and the only person who provides for them. It is therefore very important to her to keep her business going and to do well.

Translated from Spanish by Montserrat Zuckerman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy staples for food preparation and sweets

loans.name: Souphorn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Souphorn A. is the leader of a six-member loan group in Sombour Village, Kandal Province. This group loan will be used to purchase more materials, supplies, and other items that will be help the group members to improve their workplaces.  

Mrs. Souphorn A. and her husband, Mr. Thy Thouch, are farmers who own a 1-hectare (~2.5 acres) field on which they grow rice. 
They own a water machine to support their field, but they now have a problem because the soil in the field is infertile. Mrs. Souphorn A. has decided to ask for a loan 600,000 Riel from AMK to buy fertilizer. She will use the rest of the loan to buy gasoline for the water machine. 

Mrs. Souphorn A. has two children. One of her children is employed in a garment factory and the other one is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her field and gasoline for her water machine

loans.name: María Consuelo

texts.es: María Consuelo P. P. de 42 años de edad, reside en el departamento de San salvador. Vive  junto a sus padres y tres hijos menores de edad, los cuales depende por completo de María. Ella posee una venta de productos varios como gel para el cabello, pasta dental, pegamento, papel higiénico, entre otros productos más. Su venta está ubicada frente al mercado de Santa Tecla, ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad. Este lugar es muy estratégico, ya que siempre está muy lleno de una gran cantidad de personas. María solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar una mayor cantidad de productos varios, sobre todo pastas dentales, ya que son estas las que más se venden en el lugar. María es una señora muy responsable quien trabaja mucho para poder brindarles todo lo necesario a sus hijos y ayudarle a sus padres con los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
María Consuelo P. P. is 42 years old and lives in the Department of San Salvador. She lives with her parents and her three children, all minors and dependent solely on her. She owns a stand where she sells a variety of products, such as hair gel, toothpaste, glue and toilet paper, among others. The stand is located in front of the Santa Tecla market, in the Department of La Libertad. It is very well located as the market is always full of people. María has asked for a loan to buy a greater quantity of products, in particular toothpaste, since these are the top selling items at her stand. María is very dependable, she works hard to be able to provide for her children and to help her parents with expenses at home.

Translated from Spanish by Montserrat Zuckerman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic need items for sale.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Alma, age 39, is a farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. She tills a 2-hectare (~ 5-acre) rice field to make a living for her family. She’s the mother of two children, the eldest of whom is 14 years old. She needs additional capital to finance her farm. She joined in Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and requested a loan of 15,000 Php. She will use the loan to purchase farm supplies and improve her rice field.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Ngeik

texts.en: Mrs. Ngeik N. is forty-eight years old and lives in Chey Otdum village in Kandal province. She buys and resells fish to earn income. Her husband, Mr. Nguon Vorl, is a farmer who rents a two-hectare field of land to grow lotus. Now, Mrs. Ngeik N. has asked for a loan to buy more lotuses for growing and to buy more fish to resell in order to increase their income. She is the mother of two children, one of whom is a chef's assistant while the other is studying in the local public school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more lotuses to grow and fish to resell.

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en: Rice farming is the main source of income for Conchita, 47.  She supports two children in her family.  Her 2-hectare rice field is just enough to provide their basic needs. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, to seek a loan to finance her business with a low interest rate. She’s requesting 15,000 Philippine pesos to buy farm necessities and sustain her family.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is a 49-year-old rice farmer. She started tilling her farm to raise money for the entire family's needs. She has only one child. She is doing the best she can to be a good mother and a good wife. 

She would like to apply for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to fund her farm by buying the farming necessities. With this loan, she won’t need to apply for a loan with loan sharks who charge a higher interest rate.

loans.use: Farm inputs

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie maintains a one hectare rice field in Norala, South Cotabato. She started farming back in August 2007. She is now 41 years old with 4 children to support. Her eldest is still 20 years old. She strives hard so that she can send them to school and have them finish their studies.

Elsie joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and asked for financial support for her business. She requested a loan of 15,000 PhP to purchase fertilizer and seeds for the farm.

loans.use: fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Emelita

texts.en:
Emelita is 50 years old and is living in Norala, South Cotabato. She has a hog-raising business. She started her business back in 2007 with six piglets. She is a mother of 6 children, and her eldest is still 27 years old. She receives enough income for her family from her piggery.

She would like to request a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to purchase feed and vitamins for the pigs. This is very helpful to sustain her family and business.

loans.use: feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Dervina

texts.en:
Dervina P. is from the village of Tablon, Digkilaan Iligan City. She is 36 years old. Dervina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Dervina owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Dervina has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Dervina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dervina is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Dervina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tablon, Digkilaan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is a rice farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. She is 40 years with four children. Her eldest child is 20 years old. She started farming a rice field back in 2007. Her harvest is the main source of income her family depends on.

Now she would like to request a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. worth Php 15,000 to expand her farm and supply the necessary materials needed for her rice field.

loans.use: fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Nhoek

texts.en:
C., 38, is a low-income person who lives with other family members in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is married with two school-aged children. Her husband helps to support the family by farming rice. 

C. sells sugar. She buys palm sugar in bulk from palm climbers and she then delivers the sugar to the market where she sells it retail. She is able to generate an average of $6 each day to pay for food for her family. 

Because sugar prices are especially low this season, C. wants to buy a larger quantity of palm sugars to store in her home, and then sell when the price rises. To make that possible, C. decided to take a loan of $500 from HKL, a Kiva field partner.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of palm sugar

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en: 52-year-old Evangeline is living in Norala, South Cotabato and has a rice-farming business.  She’s married to Nestor and has 2 children.  She has a 1-hectare rice field that gives them their daily needs. Her business started up in 2007. She is now requesting a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to buy farm inputs necessary for her farm.

loans.use: farm inputs

loans.name: Mrs. Neang Cheng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan group which consists of nine members is located in Preaek Char village in Kandal province. Mrs. Neang C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members; they will use the loan which they obtained for different purposes.

Mrs. Neang C. and her husband, Mr. Keom Ley Chhem, are farmers who own 1-hetare of land to cultivate rice to support their family. In the rice field, this family has a problem, because their rice field has a lot of insects, but they did not have money to buy pesticide. Thus, Mrs. Neang C. decided to apply for a loan to buy pesticide to support their rice field to increase their yield this current year. She is the mother of one child, who is attending local public school.

loans.use: To buy pesticide for her farm

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina, 43 years old, is a rice farmer. She owns a 1-hectare farm that she hopes can provide her family enough income to buy adequate food, clothing and other basic needs. She has five children. Her eldest is only 19.

She is asking for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farming necessities to grow her harvest.

loans.use: farm inputs

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: 50-year-old Helen is living in Norala, South Cotabato and has a rice-farming business. She started tilling her farm back in 1980. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and has requested a loan of Php 15,000.  The loan will be helpful to expand her business so it can become sustainable in the future.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn, 36, is a rice farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. She farms a rice field. She supports her family with three children; the eldest is 14 years old. She works hard in order to have a good harvest.

She is limited in her capital, and that’s why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to access a loan. She’s requesting 15,000 Php to support her business by buying seeds and farm materials.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
The rice-farming business of Joy is improving with the financial help offered by micro-finance institutions. She has been a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., an MFI, since the year 2008. She is able to finance her business with a small interest charge.

Now she has requested a loan of 15,000 Php to continue to support her rice field. She is glad that her daily needs are met by the income she receives.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius, age 32, started his rice farm in 2007. His rice field is in Norala, South Cotabato. He’s married to Maria and has two children. His farm helps his family meet their basic needs. Currently he is applying for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He joined CEVI in October, 2007 to access a loan with only 2% interest. This loan will help him a lot getting some farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Marilyn's Group

texts.en: Marilyn S. is from the village of Dipacamo, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Marilyn is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Marilyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn provides manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2010, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the first loan taken out by Marilyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Mrs. S., age 22, earns a living by working in a garment factory. She gets a fixed salary of $70 per month to help solve her family's financial problems. S. has a partner in her husband who farms a rice crop. They are parents of a child who attends school. The daily revenue of the family is not sufficient to support them. Thus, S. has decided to apply for a loan to purchase piglets to breed and pig food. She is hopeful that this will provide her with extra profit.  

S. was busy working, so her husband appears in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to breed and pig food

loans.name: Rea Richel

texts.en: Rea, 23 years old, is a pig farmer. She has one child. Her piggery is their only livelihood. The income she makes from raising pigs helps her family buy adequate food, clothing and other basic needs. She would like a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional piglets and feed.

loans.use: To buy feed and piglets

loans.name: Chantha's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha Y. is a grocer and her husband, Mr. Chhoeun Brak, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to support his family. No matter how hard this family works with their field and business, they do not earn enough money. Thus, Mrs. Chantha Y. decided to apply for a loan to buy more groceries to expand her business. She is the mother of three children: two attend the local public school while the other is too young for school. 

Mrs. Chantha Y. is the leader for this group which consists of six members from Taok Ma village in Kandal province. Each member will use the loan for different purposes. (Mrs. Sok Kong T. could not come for the photo, so her husband is presented instead.)

loans.use: To buy more groceries

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita, 38, is a pig grower. She has one child. She wants to grow her small piggery. In that way, she will be able to provide the basic needs for her family.

She would like to apply for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to buy feed and hog supplements.

loans.use: Feeds

loans.name: Irenea

texts.en: Irenea C. runs a sari-sari (variety retail store) selling food and daily use products in her community. She is 54 years old, married and has two grown up children. She is from the village of Digkilaan, Iligan City. Irenea has been in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Irenea joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Irenea is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rice farming is the main source of income for Rosalinda, 51. Her business is located in Norala, South Cotabato. She has a good harvest when the weather is good and no pests attack. She is the mother of seven children. Her eldest is 26 years old.

She requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, of 15,000 Philippine pesos to have additional capital for her business. She would like to send her children to school to study for them to have a bright future.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley supports the basic needs of her family through rice farming. She has five children in Norala, South Cotabato. Her eldest is 22 years old. She manages a rice field that is the main source of income for the family.

She’s asking for a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, to finance her business. This loan will be used to buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vicky, 32, is living in Norala, South Cotabato. She’s married to Efril and has three children. She has a rice field, which is her family's source of income. She started her business in August 2007.

She is requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, to buy farm supplies and fertilizers necessary for the farm.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Aurea

texts.en: Aurea T.'s main source of income comes from making and selling snacks and delicacies in her community. She is 49 years old, married and has five school-age children. They are from the village of Hinaplanon, Iligan City. Aurea has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Aurea joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Aurea is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Ines' Group

texts.en: Ines D. is from the village of Dadda, Tuguegarao City. She is 56 years old. Ines is the group leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Ines is married and has eight children. To make a living, Ines provides laundry services in the local community. Ines has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2008, Ines joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ines has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Ines is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase equipment to improve the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase equipment to improve the business

loans.name: Ouch

texts.en:
Ouch B. owns and operates a small enterprise buying and selling mature rice. She is a 56-year-old married woman and a good mother to her married daughter. She lives with her husband, who works as a civil service officer for a ministry. 

Ouch B. runs her rice trade from her home. Mostly of her clients are her nearby neighbors who bring their rice directly to her house to sell. She also saves hundreds of kilograms of rice before selling it for a profit. Because the rice matures in this season, Ouch B. wants to order a larger amount of rice to resell, but she lacks capital, so, she is looking for assistance from HKL, a Kiva field partner.

loans.use: To order a large amount of rice.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en: Rosita P. is from the village of Santiago, Iligan City. She is 50 years old. Rosita is separated from her spouse and has three adult children. To make a living, she operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling scrap metal and other used products in the local community. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Rosita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Rosita from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Shirley's Group

texts.en: Shirley M. is from the village of Bantay, Solana, Cagayan. She is 28 years old. Shirley is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Shirley is married and has three young children. To make a living, Shirley raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Shirley is just starting this business. In 2010, Shirley joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shirley is requesting a new loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Shirley from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Najeba Emam Group

texts.en:
This is the Najeba Emam Group. This group is made up of two female members. Najeba is the group leader. She is married and has 6 children. She wants to take a loan for her husband. Her husband has a retail shop and he wants to use this loan to buy more stock for his shop. 

The second member is Khoory Gull. She wants a loan for her son. He sells fresh fruit and vegetables from a cart. With this loan, he wants to expand his business. 

They have requested a group loan of 28000 Afghani to change the status of their businesses and their life. They admire this effective process.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her husband's retail shop

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Mrs. Hun D. cares for three school-aged children. To earn money, Hun D. sews clothes in the garment industry. Another source of family income is her husband’s construction business. In addition, the family cultivates a rice crop as their annual business. The rice drying season is approaching, but Hun D. lacks some farm supplies, so she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, a pump, and rice seed to support her field. 

(Mrs. Hun D.’s husband appears in the photograph.)

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, a pump, and rice seed

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Mrs. C., age 33, resides in the best territory of Kampong Chhnang Province. Here she built a small grocery store in the village where she sells a few cooking ingredients to the neighbors for a profit. She is able to earn a daily income of $4 a day to contribute the daily needs of her family. She has a good partner in her husband who helps feed the family by working in construction. C. has a young child who attends a primary school. C. is taking her loan to raise capital for her grocery business. With the rest of the loan, she will buy some children's toys to sell.

loans.use: Capital for her grocery business

loans.name: Toem

texts.en: Mrs. S. is a 42-year-old farmer with many years of farming experience. She is a married mother of six children, four of whom are students. One of her childre is married and another one is a fruit plantation worker. She has a partner in her husband who allows her to plant crops. S. is requesting a loan to buy supplies for her crop-growing activities.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her farm

loans.name: Rahima Akbar Group

texts.en:
Robaba is the leader of Rahima Akbar Group. She is married and has 5 children. She assembled a group of four members, each of whom has a different business. Robaba will use this loan for her tailoring business. She wants to buy a new sewing machine for her business. 

The second member of Rahima Akbar group is Kamila who wants a loan for her son, who sells dried fruit from a car. With this loan, he wants to complete his inventory. 

The third member, Taiba, wants a loan for her husband. He sells fresh fruit from a cart. With this loan, he wants to buy more fresh fruit for his cart. 

The last member of Rahima Akbar group is Rahima, who is a carpet weaver. With this loan, she wants to buy more equipment for her business. 

They requested a group loan of 40000 Afghani and to further their work and be good clients of Kiva and AFS. Robaba ensures that they can repay the loan on time and says that she can control the whole group. She would like to thank everybody who helps with this loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine for her tailoring business

loans.name: Hang

texts.en:
Hang S. was born in 1954. She is a married woman who is blessed with five children. Two of her children are married, three are single students, and one is an employee in a private company. Her husband's Chea, age 52, grows rice to earn a living. 

Hang S. has built a pigpen behind her house where she raises many pigs to earn a living. Hang S. always pays a lot of money for taxis because she doesn’t own a vehicle. To solve the problem, she has applied for a loan of $1000 to buy a new motorcycle to use for transportation.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie C. is from the village of Digkilaan in Iligan City. She is 38 years old. Rosemarie is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Rosemarie owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells a variety of daily-use products and beverages in the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Rosemarie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Rosemarie's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Fawzia Saliha Group

texts.en:
This is the Fawzia Saliha Group. It has four members. They would like to improve and develop their businesses.

Hakimullah is the group leader. He wants a loan for his brother who has a retail shop. With this loan, he wants to buy materials that he needs for his shop. 

Fawzia wants a loan for her husband who sells fresh fruit from a cart. He wants to buy more fresh fruit for his cart and expand his business. 

Saliha has tailoring business in her house. She has arranged a small room where she sews different kinds of clothes and has a good number of clients.
With the loan, she wants to buy an electric sewing machine because she has lots of problems using the old one. 

The last member, Farhad, wants a loan for his sister who is tailor. With this loan, she wants to buy more cloth for her business. 

They have requested a group loan of 40000 Afghani. They would like to note the effectiveness of Kiva process and its effect on the progress of their businesses.

loans.use: To buy material for his brother's retail shop.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa D. is from the village of Digkilaan in Iligan City. She is 39 years old. Elsa is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Elsa owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells a variety of food and daily-use products in the local community. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Elsa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase more products to sell. This will be Elsa's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Waheeda Farid Group

texts.en:
This is the Waheeda Farid Group. This group is made up of four members: M. Ajmal, Ahmad Jawed, Farida ,and Waheeda. 

Ajmal, who is in the middle in the photograph, is the leader of the Waheeda Farid Group. He is a 30-year-old married man with two children. He wants a loan for his wife's tailoring business. With this loan, his wife wants to buy cloth and other things for her business. 

The second member of this group is Ahmad Jawed. He wants a loan for his brother who has a retail shop. With this loan, he wants to buy more food for his shop. 

Farida wants a loan for her brother who has a stationary shop. With this loan, he wants to buy notebooks, pens, and writing paper. 

The last member, Waheeda, wants a loan for her husband who has a flower shop. With this loan, he wants to buy more flowers and other things for his shop. 

They have requested a group of loan 40000 Afghani. They would like to say "lots of thanks" to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy cloth for his wife's tailoring business

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna D. is from the village of Bagong Silang in Iligan City. She is 53 years old. Edna is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Edna runs a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells food, soft drinks, and daily-use products in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over 35 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Edna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be Edna's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

texts.en:
Feliza G. is from the village of Villa Concepcion in Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 61 years old. Feliza is the leader of a 19-member group loan sponsored by ASKI. loans.name: Lucrecia's Group

texts.en: Lucrecia B. is from the village of Bacolod, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 36 years old. Lucrecia is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Lucrecia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lucrecia raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Lucrecia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2010, Lucrecia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucrecia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the first loan taken out by Lucrecia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Gulestan Boostan Group

texts.en: Gulestan K. is the leader of Gulestan Boostan group. He is married and the father of 6 children and he lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. After working hard, he made a group of 3 members. Each one of them is busy with different tasks. Gulestan is busy in his retail shop. With this loan he wants to buy foods for his shop. The second member of Gulestan Boostan group is Nowa Gull, who takes a loan for her husband who has a cart of fresh fruits. With this loan he wants to buy more fresh fruits for his cart. The third one is Zakira, who is busy in quilt-making business. With this loan she wants to buy cloths and cotton for her business. They requested a group loan of 42000 Afghani to further their work and be a good client for Kiva and AFS. Gulestan ensures that they can repay the loan on the time and he can control the whole group. Finally, he would like to thank every body that helps with this process of lending in Afghanistan and other poor counties.

loans.use: They wants to buying more tools for their stocks

loans.name: Abdull Monir

texts.en:
Abdull Monir is 34 years old. He is educated. He is one of the staff of the Army Hospital of Afghanistan. He has been involved in this career for more than 15 years. He needs a 30,000 Afghani loan for his personal use, but no one is available to lend him this much money. After so many problems, he found the AFS office.

Therefore, he has requested an individual loan of 30,000 Afghanis to solve his family problems. He is happy with this loan process. Since he found AFS and applied for his first loan, he hasn't faced any difficulties; therefore, he would like to thank lenders around the world who help those who really want to expand their businesses.

loans.use: Personal use

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander is married. He lives in Vasilyevka. Alexander sells household retail items in the central marketplace of his home town. His wife is actively helping him with the trade. He started this business over 8 years ago. Currently, he receives about 8,000 Grivnyas of income each month.  

Alexander is seeking a 13,000 Grivnya loan to increase his working capital. This entrepreneur works in favorable conditions with few competitors and affordable competitive prices. Alexander is an achiever and a hard worker. He is ready to invest all of his free time and energy in further successful growth of his venture.

loans.use: to increase his working capital

loans.name: Sulaina

texts.en:
Sulaina is a 37-year-old married married mother of six children aged between 7 and 17 years, all attending school. Sulaina also takes care of additional family members and resides in a rented four-room house with eight people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets two meals a day.

Sulaina owns a ladies' salon in Kisaasi, a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She incurs transport costs to and from buying creams and cosmetics in Kampala city shops mainly in Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Uganda. Working seven days a week, Sulaina receives an average of 30 customers a day and works on all categories of children and women. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees for her children and rent for her business and residence. Her major business challenges are the rainy season which hinders her customers in reaching out to her because she works in a muddy place.

Sulaina has been in this business for four years and with MCDT for six years, now servicing her twelfth loan and working with the same group mates. Sulaina joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more hair relaxers and cosmetics. She aspires to see her business grower bigger and to develop a bridal salon .

loans.use: To buy more cream relaxers and hair conditioners

loans.name: Annielice's Group

texts.en: Annielice R. is from the village of Punit, Benito Soliven, Isabela. She is 56 years old and is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Annielice R.' Group. Annielice is married and has two school-aged children. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling eggs in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Annielice joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Annielice is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married with two grown daughters. She lives and works in Melitopol, selling women’s clothing in the central marketplace.

Olga launched her small venture eleven years ago and has gained much experience and loyal clientele ever since. Presently, Olga has 10,000 Grivnyas worth of inventory and makes about 3,000 Grivnyas of profit.

Olga is requesting a 10,000 Grivnya loan to increase her working capital. She hopes to continue developing her business and improving her living standards. She has proved to be a reliable and solvent client.

Olga is planning to use generated profits to pay her daughter’s college fees.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

Alma has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Alma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Norie

texts.en:
Norie is a tenant on a 2-hectare rice field. The income she gets from the farm is the only means to meet her family’s needs. She got married to her husband Felipe in 1983 and they now have nine children. Norie and her husband want to have their own farm to till so they can increase their earnings.

Norie is applying for a loan of 7,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies like fertilizers and seeds.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en: Merlita farms to earn income for her family. She tills a one-hectare rice field in her town in Agusan Del Sur. She is 32 years old, married and has three children. Her oldest child is only eight years old and she wants to start saving early for their future. She applied for a loan from CEVI to assist her business financially. She is asking for 7,000 PHP, which she will use to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies needed at her farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Yuryi

texts.en:
Yuryi is married with six children, four boys and two girls. He lives in Novomoskovsk but travels all over Ukraine delivering freight and farm produce. Yuryi has been in this business for two years. Presently, he receives over $625 of income each month. 

Yuryi is seeking a 6,000 UAH loan for truck maintenance purposes. He is hoping to keep his vehicle running efficiently which will help him serve more clients and bring him a stable income. Yuryi has a big family and needs to provide for its needs. He is an active and cheerful person and a businessman with integrity.

loans.use: truck maintenance

loans.name: Alvard

At the same time she is engaged in raising livestock; she has cows, sheep and pigs. Her family helps Alvard in her business and with the livestock farming as well. Alvard seeks 1.100.000 AMD to buy candy and snacks for her shop.

loans.use: To buy candy and snacks for her shop

loans.name: Eseza Tumugirwa ‘S Group

texts.en:
Eseza is a 34-year-old married woman with five children between the ages of 10 and 20. All her children go to school. Eseza takes care of additional family members. She rents and lives in a two-room house with five people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. 

Eseza owns a stall where she sells secondhand clothes.  She incurs transportation costs to and from buying the clothes at the Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda.  She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.  She works seven days a week. She receives an average of thirty customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both on a retail and a wholesale basis.  

Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, paying school fees for her children, and paying rent for her business and her residence. Her major business challenge is the rainy season, which hinders her customers' ability to reach her because she works in a muddy place. 

Eseza has been in this business for ten years and with the Kiva field partner, MCDT (Micro-Credit for Development and Transformation), for eight years, now servicing her 16th loan, working with the same group mates. Eseza joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of secondhand clothes. She hopes to see her business grower bigger so she can sell on a wholesale basis only.

loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand clothes

loans.name: Khwaja Muainudin

Therefore, he has requested an individual loan of 50,000 Afghanis to start buying more food and some necessary things for his retail food shop. He would like to thank all lenders, Kiva and AFS in Afghanistan.

After hard work, Akram made up a group of two members who have requested a group loan of 26000 Afghani to expand their businesses and make a good monthly income for their families. Akram wants to take a loan for his fresh fruit cart. With this loan he will be able to buy fresh fruit for his cart. loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros is a 68-year-old widow from the mountainous city of Tanay, Rizal Province, in the Philippines. She is blessed with an only daughter, Melanie, who is 35 years old and a high school graduate. Her daughter has a family of her own. Even at her older age; Milagros still dreams of the best for her family.

In 2004, Milagros joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. When she received her first loan, she invested the money in the selling of different small items and later expanded the business with additional products. She now also raises hogs.

Now on her eighth loan, she requested 20,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. She is optimistic that her business will grow since she already has regular customers requesting orders from her.

She dreams of having a stall in the market where she can sell her products, building a concrete house and also experiencing a life that is far away from poverty.

loans.use: Additional capital to sell different small items and the remaining money will be used for hog raising

loans.name: Tita Linda

texts.en:
Tita Linda J., 40 years old, is a hardworking mother. She lives in Calahan, Cardona, Rizal, Philippines with her husband and five children. She and her husband, Ronald, have only high school level educations. They come from poor families. They realize that their lack of education has led to their poverty, and they want a better life for their children. Tita Linda and Ronald hope their children will complete their studies in college.

They decided to join the Kiva field partner, ASHI, to obtain capital for their business, which is fishing. They have requested a loan of 15,000 PHP. The loan will be used to pay for fishnets, bamboo, rope and other materials for their fishing business.

In the future, the couple hopes to invest in their own pump boat. Tita Linda also dreams that soon she will have a larger area to store her fishing materials.

loans.use: to buy fishnets, bamboo, rope and other materials for their fishing business.

Now on her 3rd loan, she requested 15,000 PHP as additional capital for her business. She is positive that her business will grow since she already has regular customers from other villages requesting orders.

She dreams of having a space in the market where she can sell her dried fish. She hopes for a successful business that can provide them with a good life that is far away from poverty. She also dreams of building a concrete house to live in with a happy family.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a 39-year-old married woman with five children aged between 18 and 25 years, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a three-roomed house where she lives with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets two meals a day.

Jackline owns a fish stall and works in Naguru, a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of twenty-five customers a day, selling to all categories of people both wholesale and retail.

Jackline incurs transport costs to and from buying fish from Gaba landing site but her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are the transportation of fish from Gaba to her stall in Naguru, seasonality which makes her business difficult, and the rainy season which disturbs her a lot because she works in an open place.

Jackline has been in her business for ten years and with MCDT for eight years. She is servicing her seventeenth loan working with the same group members. Jackline joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women at the village level.

Jackline wants to use this loan to buy more fish. She is hoping to see her business grower bigger and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her stall

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: N. Jeanne est née en 1958 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Jeanne s'est installée depuis 30 ans à Adjarra Sota à quelques kilomètres de Porto-Novo. Mariée à HONFO Kinvoedo, un marchand, Jeanne est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Jeanne vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Adjarra. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la maison. Jeanne n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Jeanne mène comme activité, la vente d'oignons et d'igname au marché d'Adjarra. Jeanne vend également ses produits à son domicile, et s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est depuis 10 ans que Jeanne exerce cette activité, une activité qui lui génère de revenu qu'elle utilise pour subvenir à ses différents besoins. Jeanne a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Jeanne souhaite augmenter davantage le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre aux différents besoins de ses clients. Cependant, Jeanne ne réunit pas assez de fonds pour renforcer son activité. C’est pourquoi Jeanne sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Jeanne N. was born in 1958 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She settled some thirty years ago in Adjarra Sota, a few kilometres from Porto-Novo. Married to Kinvoedo HONFO, a merchant, Jeanne is mother to four children, all attending school. She lives together with her children and husband in Adjarra. The couple share the household expenses. Jeanne has not been to school. To meet her various expenses, Jeanne sells onions and yams in the Adjarra market. She also sells these products from her home, and gets her supplies from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Jeanne has been performing this activity for the past ten years, which generates the income she uses to cover her various expenses. Jeanne has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, both of which were fully reimbursed. She would like to increase her stock of supplies and respond better to the diverse needs of her customers. However, she is unable to gather sufficient funds to reinforce her business. This is why she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy baskets of onions and yams

loans.name: Junie

texts.en:
Junie C. is from the village of Naawan Misamis Oriental. He is 49 years old. Junie is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Junie owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling sack bags in the local community. Junie has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Junie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Junie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Junie from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en: Hadjah is 42 years old and married with six children aged between 10 and 23 years. All her children go to school. She rents a four-room house where she stays with eight people. Hadjah takes care of additional family members. The family has no access to electricity or piped water and gets two meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying baking flour and cooking oil. Hadjah fries samosas and chapatti in Kawempe. She works in a semi-urban area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala.  She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 30 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at wholesale and retail.  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees for her children and rent for her residence. Her major business challenges are transporting the baking flour, cooking oil and cowpeas to her business premises; seasonality, which makes her business difficult; and the rainy season, which disturbs her a lot because she works in an open area. Hadjah has been in this business for 10 years and with MCDT for five years. This is her 10th loan working with the same group mates. Hadjah joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women in the village. She wants to use this loan to buy more cartons of baking flour, jerry cans of cooking oil and a sack of cowpeas. She hopes to see her business grower bigger and to start employing three people.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients
